title: 105_hr1695
content: The "Retirement Savings Commission Act of 1997" establishes the Commission on Retirement Savings with specific duties. The Commission on Retirement Savings is tasked with studying private pension and savings issues, recommending policies to expand access to retirement savings vehicles, and addressing trends in coverage of American workers, personal saving rates, changes in retirement plans, demographic trends, and special retirement needs. The Commission on Retirement Savings is studying the special retirement needs of women, part-time workers, and temporary workers, as well as the amounts of retirement income needed to replace preretirement income. They are also looking at the sources of retirement income in the US, past legislative changes affecting retirement plans, and ways to encourage employers to adopt workplace retirement plans efficiently. The Commission on Retirement Savings is examining the adoption of workplace retirement plans by employers, especially small businesses, the funding needed for existing and new federal incentives for retirement savings, the role of tax-deferred individual retirement savings vehicles, and how tax expenditures for pension and retirement savings are scored for budget purposes. The Commission on Retirement Savings is studying workplace retirement plans, federal incentives for retirement savings funding, tax-deferred individual retirement savings, and how tax expenditures for pension and retirement savings are scored for budget purposes. Recommendations will focus on expanding retirement plan coverage, encouraging adequate retirement income accumulation, stimulating personal savings, and promoting workplace access to retirement plans. The Commission on Retirement Savings aims to encourage workplace retirement plan participation, ensure benefit security, help low-wage workers save for retirement, and simplify regulatory requirements. Recommendations require unanimous approval from all 16 members to be considered for inclusion in the report. The Commission on Retirement Savings will not make recommendations on Social Security or programs that increase the federal budget deficit without offsetting measures. The term "workplace retirement plan" is defined as any financial vehicle mentioned in section 219(g)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 16 members appointed within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, including appointments by the President, Speaker of the House, Senate majority leader, and House minority leader. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, Senate majority leader, and House minority leader. Members must have qualifications in Congress, business, labor, pension administration, or retirement income policy. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled within 30 days, and members receive compensation. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by officials, serving without pay but receiving travel expenses. Ten members constitute a quorum, with meetings called by co-chairpersons. Decisions are made by consensus or majority vote. SEC. 5. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Commission shall have two co-directors of staff recommended by each co-chairperson. Additional professional staff will be appointed as needed. The co-directors will report to their respective co-chairpersons and manage daily operations. The Commission will appoint and determine the pay of the co-directors and staff. Appointments may be made without following certain civil service laws. The Commission may procure temporary services under title 5, United States Code, at rates determined appropriate. Federal agencies may detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Administrator of General Services shall provide administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may procure temporary services under title 5, United States Code, at rates determined appropriate, and federal agencies may detail personnel to assist. The Administrator of General Services shall provide administrative support services on a reimbursable basis necessary for the Commission to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission is granted powers under Section 6. The Commission under Section 6 has the authority to hold hearings, public sessions, and receive testimony and evidence. It can also administer oaths to witnesses. Members, committees, or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can gather information directly from federal agencies. The Commission can gather necessary information from federal agencies and conduct public surveys to carry out its duties under this Act. It can also use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission has the authority to make purchases, contract for services, and accept gifts to assist in its work. Gifts received are deposited in the Treasury and can be used by the Commission. Accepted property is considered a gift to the United States for tax purposes. The Commission can accept voluntary services as needed, considered a gift to the United States. The Commission will submit a report to the President, Senate leaders, and House leaders, reviewing required matters, providing analysis, and recommendations within 1 year and 90 days. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998 to carry out this Act.
